task.summary:
Added and updated some nested functions within the Table.check_all_intersections() method to look at all the intersecting points of the averaged lines and figure out which ones to keep. Here's the algorithm: 1. check to see how far each point is from the center of the frame 2. separate the points by what quadrant of the frame they are in, such as upper-right 'ur' or bottom-left 'bl' and store in a dict 3. sort the list in each quadrant by their distances from the center 4. iterate through the quadrants, and grab the minimum center-dist point from each. since the playfield is flat and formless, I am assuming for now that the minimum lines in each quadrant will give us the playfield lines, assuming we aren't missing lines in the detection stage. 5. check all of the points in each quadrant agains the groups assigned to the good group list, and remove any that are "inline" with any of the known good points. if they share an x or a y value, we know that they cannot be entirely new lines representing a new part of the table
I have not yet sorted and assigned these remaining point-groups to their corresponding table part. That's next.
At this point I certainly haven't PEP8'd it.

Got rid of some old unused functions and methods, and tons of old commented out lines. made the check_all_intersections method returns the list of known good points. replaced the set_boxes method with one that takes those known good points and sets them as the tables playbox, pocketbox, and tablebox attributes. added a drawboxes method to table that is called from play_frame() for if you want to be able to see the boundary boxes on the live playback.

Removed some more old unused functions and re-organized the Table.find_balls() method a bit. I added the ability to have different ball detection settings. I also Started the ball class.
Next, I need to figure out how to make it figure out which balls are the from one frame to the next, so that I can draw the directional prediction lines

Added FPS tracking. Also added a global copy of each frame so that ball objects can easily access them for color checking. Added circles and balls lists to the Table class. Added a find_real_balls method to table to sort through the circles and decide whether to actually grant them ballship. created calculate_radius_square method to find the upper left and bottom right corners of each detected ball so that the color can be averaged easily. Also started adding to the Ball class. they now automatically take a crop of the image for color averaging. I haven't yet implemented the actual averaging operation. Also changed the cv.waitKey from triggering when esc is pressed to just cv.waitKey(1). I don't know why, but in a test, having a specific waitkey seemed to lower the frame rate considerably.

Added some descriptions for each of the global settings. find_balls now appends the circles found in each frame to the Table.circlehistory list, and deletes the oldest item, keeping the list ballframebuffer frames long. also made it so that get_ball_color is passed the balls number in the list, so that a seperate debug image can be output for each ball.

Started appending circles and balls to table's circlehistory and ballhistory lists. Added the findlastposition method to the Ball class, which takes the ballhistory list and finds the ball with the smallest difference in distance. It then updates its lastpos and lastdist with the previous position, and the distance between the two points respectively. Added is_moving method which looks at the two points (current and past) and returns True if the distance is greater than the movementthresh. Started the get_movement_direction method which identifies the slope, and will then decide where to draw the motion line. Also made a global version of get_dist, and added the ability to specify whether you want the absolute value distance, or the relative, with the first point being the most recent, and the second being the historic.

Renamed the Ball class to Circle, so that I can have a subclass Ball that is only for graduated circles. Added a distance threshold for the circles find_last_position method that returns None for lastpos and dist if the distance is too high. This is to make it easy while iterating to know where HoughCircles missed failed ball in a certain frame. Also added to get_movement_path. It currently just returns a line from the current center to its center from the previous frame.

Completely revised the distance detection structure. I removed all methods from the Circle class except for those used to grab the color within that circle, and I moved the ball-continuity process into the Table.find_ball_groups method. I added a global frame number variable that I use for debugging. Basically, every frame, the new set of circles found is weighed against those in the last frame. Circles that seem to be contiguous are put into a group with their selves from past frames and added to Table.grouped_circles. I also added a color checking in addition to distance checking to help make sure the balls are the same. The major additions all happened within find_ball_groups. I added a frames folder to debug_images, and it is currently set up to draw the circles found in each group over every frame. Each group is drawn with a different color for better debugging.

Created the Ball subclass of Circle. So far, the only thing that's new from the circle is a .past attribute, which is a list of Circle objects that were deemed within the Table's find_ball_groups method to be the same ball from past frames. The find_ball_groups method works about the same as it did in the last commit, except it has been adapted so that, rather than just using a list of lists of past locations for each ball stored directly as a table attribute, the table's list is now full of ball objects. I added a whole bunch of magic to the Ball class, so that they can be indexed and appended all the same, so very little change was needed within the find_ball_groups method. I decided to switch to Ball objects so that I could more easily compare color and collisions with methods within the Ball class. Have not implemented any yet.

I restructured the decision tree within find_ball_groups so that it looks at color first, then moves on to distance. This seems to work much better. It seems to be able to group balls moving very quickly, even if there is a missing frame. Huge improvement.
I also added a method to help with motion-blurred circles. Often Hough- Circles detects 2 circles on a ball when it is moving very quickly, but so far the circles have always somewhat overlapped, so I added a method that would look at all the circles from the frame, and see if any were closer together than their radii would allow in real life, and if there were, I would replace them with a point right in between the two. This improves color comparison as well.
I also made a few of the Table methods static, and rearranged them to be all together at the bottom of the Table methods.

I added cProfile to try and figure out where the speed could be improved and found that opencv imshow and imwrite were taking the majority of the time. I am now working on implementing pyglview for showing the images so that the gpu can be utilized for playback. I put all of the imwrite calls under if debug: statements, so that I could turn that on and off easily for speed tests.

Now utilizes OpenGL via pyglview to achieve up to 23 fps. The prior version, using cv.imshow, got usually only around 4 to 8 fps. It is not feasible to use this real time with a projector and camera. HOOORAY!!! I also added a livegroups option at the top, which allows you to see the group estimations live on playback, rather than saving the frames to files individually.

Now utilizes OpenGL via pyglview to achieve up to 23 fps. The prior version, using cv.imshow, got usually only around 4 to 8 fps. It is not feasible to use this real time with a projector and camera. HOOORAY!!! I also added a livegroups option at the top, which allows you to see the group estimations live on playback, rather than saving the frames to files individually

I moved some of the initialization stuff like creating the capture and viewer instances from the top of the document to the main function. I also made it so that it re-instantiates the capture object after the Table is initialized so that it doesn't lose all the frames that the table uses to find itself. I also added a global cleanframe variable that is unadulterated by lines drawn by opencv. This is important for color comparison mainly. I added a third setting under find_balls, that seems to work a little better. I added a isblurred attribute to the circle class, which is set to False by default and updated by the average_motionblur_circles method. I then updated find_ball_groups so that there is a lower regular color threshold, and one that is used only if that circle was averaged from a blur. I also added an nmissingframes attribute to the ball class, which I use to multiply the distthresh by. I also added a method under the Ball class called is_past_boundary which take a particular boundary box as an argument, and returns True if the center of the ball is beyond that boundary. I also added an inpocket attribute to the Ball class, which is set to true if the ball is outside that boundary. I also changed the colors used to show the ball groupings to use the colors of the balls themselves, rather than random bright colors. This makes it easier to know if balls switch groups, and if the color average seems accurate. The color of the circles turns to green if it goes into a pocket.

More tuning on the ball continuity stuff. I added a x2 multiplier to the nmissingframes distancethresh multiplier. I added a pastdists attribute to the Ball class that I may use to detect anomalous detections. I made it so that balls that aren't detected at the very beginning start their own ball object, which goes away if it has a few missing frames and a total .past length of 2 or less, or if it has been missing for over 20 frames. I currently have it so that it prints the bgr color tuple of each ball on the table, in the corresponding color. This is just for debugging, since there seem to be issues with balls swapping groups.
Now I plan to try to sort the iteration in find_ball_groups by color differences as a priority, as opposed to distance first like it is now. I wish myself luck refactoring all that without creating a giant mess.

The main thing that I did was to change the dist_list function to colordiffs_n_distances, which does the same thing as dist_list did, but adds color differences and sorts by them. This makes it so that similar colors take priority over close distances. I also made it so that, once a ball is in a pocket, it won't look for itself on the playfield anymore. I haven't yet set exceptions for the white ball. That needs to happen. I increased the color threshold in average_motionblur_circles to catch more. Keep an eye out for problems with that. I started with a method to detect intrusions of arms and bodies onto the table. Just started, so it's not yet doing anything. I also added the ability for balls and circles to get hsv color. Haven't used it for anything yet, but I thought I'd play around with that and see where it gets me. I added a colorpast attribute to the Ball class, which keeps a list of ballframebuffer x 3 = 15 currently, and that's used to find the average color of the ball from the past little bit, because in the case of striped balls, there were some issues. Also added nballs as a global but haven't implemented it yet. The idea is that it would know that, if there are more balls than that number in its list, the bar for baller-status needs to be raised. More tomorrow!(:

Changed the blur type in find_balls from median to Gaussian, which seems to both improve detection, and increase fps. Did some debugging in find_ball_groups. I made it so that the colorthresh was raised if the circle is white, since the queball often goes very quickly and blurs, making it look much more like the table color. I also added a .ispartial attribute to the Circle class, which looks at the mean color of each row and column within the ball crop and determines whether the circle is made from a stripe on a striped ball or something. I removed the hsv stuff for the balls to help playback speed. I deemed the detectintrusion method I had started to be time computationally intensive. Will have to come up with another solution, or just run that only every n frames.

Coolest thing: I increased the fps from ~20 to ~35 by having the table's find_balls method crop down the playfield image, rather than assigning zeros. I had to add the cropped amount back into the circle centers after, but it's way, way faster. Very happy about that.
I have also started adding the trajectory estimation lines. Currently, it takes the balls past centers and fits a line to them, then calculates where the hit-point would be on the wall. Have not yet factored in the other balls or reflection angles. That's coming. I added a movement threshold attribute to the balls that determines how far the ball has to go in a frame to draw the motion line. Also added an ismoving attribute which I think I will need when it comes to collision estimation. The ball trajectory estimation is currently all happening in the Ball's find_future_path method. I also had cProfile sort by time.
Issues: - false balls still appear on hands and clothes, and they often appear randomly, triggering the drawing of trajectory lines. That's the main issue at the moment.

Added and updated some nested functions within the Table.check_all_intersections() method to look at all the intersecting points of the averaged lines and figure out which ones to keep. Here's the algorithm: 1. check to see how far each point is from the center of the frame 2. separate the points by what quadrant of the frame they are in, such as upper-right 'ur' or bottom-left 'bl' and store in a dict 3. sort the list in each quadrant by their distances from the center 4. iterate through the quadrants, and grab the minimum center-dist point from each. since the playfield is flat and formless, I am assuming for now that the minimum lines in each quadrant will give us the playfield lines, assuming we aren't missing lines in the detection stage. 5. check all of the points in each quadrant agains the groups assigned to the good group list, and remove any that are "inline" with any of the known good points. if they share an x or a y value, we know that they cannot be entirely new lines representing a new part of the table
I have not yet sorted and assigned these remaining point-groups to their corresponding table part. That's next.
At this point I certainly haven't PEP8'd it.

Also started adding to the Ball class. they now automatically take a crop of the image for color averaging. I haven't yet implemented the actual averaging operation. Also changed the cv.waitKey from triggering when esc is pressed to just cv.waitKey(1). I don't know why, but in a test, having a specific waitkey seemed to lower the frame rate considerably.

So far, the only thing that's new from the circle is a .past attribute, which is a list of Circle objects that were deemed within the Table's find_ball_groups method to be the same ball from past frames. The find_ball_groups method works about the same as it did in the last commit, except it has been adapted so that, rather than just using a list of lists of past locations for each ball stored directly as a table attribute, the table's list is now full of ball objects. I added a whole bunch of magic to the Ball class, so that they can be indexed and appended all the same, so very little change was needed within the find_ball_groups method. I decided to switch to Ball objects so that I could more easily compare color and collisions with methods within the Ball class. Have not implemented any yet.

I also added a method to help with motion-blurred circles. This improves color comparison as well.
I also made a few of the Table methods static, and rearranged them to be all together at the bottom of the Table methods.

I am now working on implementing pyglview for showing the images so that the gpu can be utilized for playback. I put all of the imwrite calls under if debug: statements, so that I could turn that on and off easily for speed tests.

HOOORAY!!! I also added a livegroups option at the top, which allows you to see the group estimations live on playback, rather than saving the frames to files individually.

I moved some of the initialization stuff like creating the capture and viewer instances from the top of the document to the main function. I also made it so that it re-instantiates the capture object after the Table is initialized so that it doesn't lose all the frames that the table uses to find itself. I also added a global cleanframe variable that is unadulterated by lines drawn by opencv. This is important for color comparison mainly. I added a third setting under find_balls, that seems to work a little better. I added a isblurred attribute to the circle class, which is set to False by default and updated by the average_motionblur_circles method. I then updated find_ball_groups so that there is a lower regular color threshold, and one that is used only if that circle was averaged from a blur. I also added an nmissingframes attribute to the ball class, which I use to multiply the distthresh by. I also added a method under the Ball class called is_past_boundary which take a particular boundary box as an argument, and returns True if the center of the ball is beyond that boundary. I also added an inpocket attribute to the Ball class, which is set to true if the ball is outside that boundary. I also changed the colors used to show the ball groupings to use the colors of the balls themselves, rather than random bright colors. This makes it easier to know if balls switch groups, and if the color average seems accurate. The color of the circles turns to green if it goes into a pocket.

More tuning on the ball continuity stuff. I added a x2 multiplier to the nmissingframes distancethresh multiplier. I added a pastdists attribute to the Ball class that I may use to detect anomalous detections. I made it so that balls that aren't detected at the very beginning start their own ball object, which goes away if it has a few missing frames and a total .past length of 2 or less, or if it has been missing for over 20 frames. I currently have it so that it prints the bgr color tuple of each ball on the table, in the corresponding color. This is just for debugging, since there seem to be issues with balls swapping groups.
Now I plan to try to sort the iteration in find_ball_groups by color differences as a priority, as opposed to distance first like it is now. I wish myself luck refactoring all that without creating a giant mess.

The main thing that I did was to change the dist_list function to colordiffs_n_distances, which does the same thing as dist_list did, but adds color differences and sorts by them. This makes it so that similar colors take priority over close distances. I also made it so that, once a ball is in a pocket, it won't look for itself on the playfield anymore. I haven't yet set exceptions for the white ball. That needs to happen. I increased the color threshold in average_motionblur_circles to catch more. Keep an eye out for problems with that. I started with a method to detect intrusions of arms and bodies onto the table. Just started, so it's not yet doing anything. I also added the ability for balls and circles to get hsv color. Haven't used it for anything yet, but I thought I'd play around with that and see where it gets me. I added a colorpast attribute to the Ball class, which keeps a list of ballframebuffer x 3 = 15 currently, and that's used to find the average color of the ball from the past little bit, because in the case of striped balls, there were some issues. Also added nballs as a global but haven't implemented it yet. The idea is that it would know that, if there are more balls than that number in its list, the bar for baller-status needs to be raised. More tomorrow!(:

Changed the blur type in find_balls from median to Gaussian, which seems to both improve detection, and increase fps. Did some debugging in find_ball_groups. I made it so that the colorthresh was raised if the circle is white, since the queball often goes very quickly and blurs, making it look much more like the table color. I also added a .ispartial attribute to the Circle class, which looks at the mean color of each row and column within the ball crop and determines whether the circle is made from a stripe on a striped ball or something. I removed the hsv stuff for the balls to help playback speed. I deemed the detectintrusion method I had started to be time computationally intensive. Will have to come up with another solution, or just run that only every n frames.

Coolest thing: I increased the fps from ~20 to ~35 by having the table's find_balls method crop down the playfield image, rather than assigning zeros. I had to add the cropped amount back into the circle centers after, but it's way, way faster. Very happy about that.
I have also started adding the trajectory estimation lines. Currently, it takes the balls past centers and fits a line to them, then calculates where the hit-point would be on the wall. Have not yet factored in the other balls or reflection angles. That's coming. I added a movement threshold attribute to the balls that determines how far the ball has to go in a frame to draw the motion line. Also added an ismoving attribute which I think I will need when it comes to collision estimation. The ball trajectory estimation is currently all happening in the Ball's find_future_path method. I also had cProfile sort by time.
Issues: - false balls still appear on hands and clothes, and they often appear randomly, triggering the drawing of trajectory lines. That's the main issue at the moment.

I have also started adding the trajectory estimation lines. Currently, it takes the balls past centers and fits a line to them, then calculates where the hit-point would be on the wall. Have not yet factored in the other balls or reflection angles. That's coming. I added a movement threshold attribute to the balls that determines how far the ball has to go in a frame to draw the motion line. Also added an ismoving attribute which I think I will need when it comes to collision estimation. The ball trajectory estimation is currently all happening in the Ball's find_future_path method. I also had cProfile sort by time.
Issues: - false balls still appear on hands and clothes, and they often appear randomly, triggering the drawing of trajectory lines. That's the main issue at the moment.
